text:
DIFFERENTIATIONS

Basic Differentiation and Integration

Basic Integral Calculus

The derivative of a function, written dy/dx or f'(x) is the rate of change of the function at any given point. We can evaluate derivatives up to an infinite number of times, provided the function remains differentiable. And so, we can write d2y/dx2 or f''(x) for the second derivative or differential of the function. Similarly, we can take the third, fourth, fifth derivative etc.….

Below is a list of basic functions and their derivatives including sums, products and quotients. 

Function y or f(x) [ a is a constant and u/v are functions of x]

Derivative dy/dx or f'(x)

a

0

axn

a(nxn-1)

u + v  [ Derivative of sum ]

du/dx + dv/dx

uv      [ Derivative of product ]

vdu/dx + udv/dx

u/v     [ Derivative of quotient ]

[vdu/dx - udv/dx]/v2

(f(x))n [Function of a function/Chain Rule]

nf'(x)f(x)n-1

 

 

The last rule promises a very easy way to write down the derivative of a function of a function. We will apply this method to a whole number of functions when we solve problems. Note also that by applying this method, we have tacitly bypassed the chain rule which can be much of a headache. 

Q1: Evaluate the derivative of the following functions:

y=5

f(x)=2x3

y=(3x2)+(2x+1)

(X3+2x)(x+1)

(x2+5x)/x3

(x4-3x2-2)3

Solution

We will illustrate how we apply the above rules for differentiation to evaluate the derivatives of functions.

The derivative of a constant is 0. =>d/dx(5)=0

f(x)=2x3  

Using the 1st rule for the basic Integral, 

f'(x)=2(3x3-1)=2(3x2) 

:. f'(x)=6x2

Y = (3x2)+(2x+1) Applying basic differential formula and the Sum Rule simultaneously, 

dy/dx=(6x)+(2+0)= 6x+2

y = (x3+2x) (x+1) 

let u = x3+2x 

and v = x + 1 

=>du/dx = 3x2+2 and 

dv/dx=1. 

Applying the Product Rule as stated above, 

we have dy/dx = (x+1) (3x2+2) +(x3+2x) 

:.dy/dx = 4x3+3x2+4x+2.

y = (x2 + 5x)/x3 

let v = x3 and u = x2 + 5x. 

dv = 3x2 and du=2x+5. 

Applying the quotient rule, 

dy/dx=[x3 (2x+5) - (x2+5x)3x2]/(x3)2. 

=>dy/dx= (-x4 -10x3)/x6  

:. dy/dx= -(x+10)/x3

Example

f (x)= (x4-3x2-2)3

This is a function of a function i.e. f(x) is a function of x4-3x2-2 which in turn is a function of x. We are going to highlight two ways of solving this problem. We will first solve this problem by the chain rule for a function of a function. Then, we are going to apply the formula [nf'(x)f(x)n-1] to solve the same problem but in a simpler and easier way. Remember, we already said using this method helps us maneuver the chain rule.

Solution 1

Let u=x4-3x2-2 => y=u3 

du/dx=4x3-6x and dy/du=3u2. By the Chain Rule, 

dy/dx=dy/du × du/dx. 

Applying this rule, dy/dx=3u2×(4x3-6x). 

Finally, upon substitution for u=x4-3x2-2, we have

dy/dx=3(x4-3x2-2)2(4x3-6x).

Solution 2

Alternatively, we can quickly right down the differential of the above function if we use the second rule. Given y=(x4-3x2-2)3, 

n=3, f(x)=x4-3x2-2 and f'(x)=4x3-6x [derivative of f(x)]. Applying the formula dy/dx=[nf'(x)f(x)n-1],

dy/dx=3(4x3-6x)(x4-3x2-2)3-1

:. dy/dx=3(x4-3x2-2)2(4x3-6x) as required.

Q2: What is the slope of the curve 3x2-3x+2 at the point x=-4?

Solution

The derivative of the curve represents the slope at any point. 

dy/dx=6x-3 :. dy/dx|x=-4 = 6(-4)-3= -27

 

Example

The first derivative of y = (2 + 3x)4 at x=-1 is

A. 12, B. -12, C. 4, D. -4

B (2005/2006, no 12)

y = (2 + 3x)4

 4(2 + 3x)3

3 = 12(2 + 3x)3

At x = -1, 

 4(2 + 3(-1))3 = -2

 

Example

Find  𝑖𝑓 𝑦 = 2𝑥2 − 𝑠𝑖𝑛2𝑥

A. 4x + 2cosx, B. 4x −2cos2x, C. 4x + 2cos2x, D. 4x— 2cosx 

 

B (2008/2009, no 4)

Given that 

y = 2𝑥2 – 𝑠𝑖𝑛2𝑥

differentiating them we have

 = 4x – 2(cos2x) 

 = 4x – 2cos2x

Example

A student dropped an object from a building 100m high. If the height of the object above the ground after t seconds is 100 + 4.9t2 m. how fast is it falling 3 seconds after it is dropped?

A. 14.7m/sec, B. 85.3m/sec, C. 29.4m/sec, D. 70.6m/sec

 

C (2008/2009, no 9).

Given that,

S = 100 + 4.9t2

S = 4.9t2 + 100

 = 2  4.9t = 9.8t

The velocity at t = 3seconds will be given by

v = 9.8(3) = 29.4m/sec

 

CURVES AND TURNING POINTS

Maxima and Minima Points Including Inflexion points

Given a curve, f(x), which simultaneously increases and also decreases in some neighborhood of x, there exists at least a turning point such that f(x) switches from increasing to decreasing or vice versa. 

 

This turning point could be a cup (U-shaped) or cap (inverted U). These are what we refer to as the minimum and maximum values respectively. At those values, f'(x) changes signs, from positive to negative derivative or vice versa.

 

The terms, "maximum" and "minimum" can be misleading. In general, maximum or minimum values do not mean absolute maximum or minimum. They only indicate the values of f(x) which mark the turning points of the curve. 

 

A curve may turn at a point but later fall far below the (minimum) turning point in some other neighborhood of x, likewise for the maximum. In this case, the turning points can not be the absolute minimum/maximum for the entire curve, only their neighborhood. 

 

It helps to think of maximum and minimum values as maximum/minimum turning point values, which states clearly there may still be higher/lower values of f(x) than the former. This does not however, rule out the possibility of having a turning point that is also absolute maximum/minimum.

 

Test for Turning Points

 

  1. At a turning point, dy/dx = 0
  2. For the maximum turning point, the sign of dy/dx changes from +ve to -ve just before and after this point.

○         => max turning point, d2y/dx2 is -ve.

  1. For the minimum turning point, the sign of dy/dx changes from -ve to +ve just before and after this point.

○        => min turning point, d2y/dx2 is +ve.

  1. Finally, there is also a different kind of turning point, which is neither a cup or cap. This is slender S-shaped turning point. This point is called a point of inflexion. 

○        At this point, d2y/dx2=0

 

Tangents and Normal to a Curve

 

A tangent to a curve is a line that touches or brushes the curve at a given point. A tangent does NOT cut/cross a curve, rather it caresses the curve at the tangent point. 

A normal to a curve is a line which cuts through the curve at right angles to the tangent point. It passes perpendicular to the given point through the curve.

 

To find the equation of a tangent or normal to a curve at a point,

  1. Find the slope/derivative, m of the curve at the required point.
  2. Using the eqn of a line, (y-y1)=m(x-x1), write down the eqn of the tangent line for the given point (x1,y1).
  3. If it's a normal you are required to find, follow step 1 and use m'= - 1/m for the slope of the line (normal).
  4. Follow step 2 above and complete the eqn of the normal with slope, m'= - 1/m in place of m.

 

Q1: Find the coordinates of the maximum and minimum points on the curve y=x3-9x2+24x and distinguish between them.

Solution

dy/dx=3x2-18x+24

At the turning points, dy/dx=0

:. 3x2-18x+24=0

Solving for x, x=4 or x=2

To determine the nature of these points, we take the second derivative.

d2y/dx2=6x-18

Substitute x=4 and x=2 respectively

d2y/dx2|x=4= 6(4)-18 = 24-18 = +6 >0

d2y/dx2|x=2= 6(2)-18 = 12-18 = -6 <0

We therefore conclude,

 x = 2 is a max point and x = 4 is a minimum point

 

Q2: Find the equation of the normal to a curve y=x(3-x2) at the point x=2.

Solution

y=x(3-x2) = 3x-x3

dy/dx= 3-3x2 :. dy/dx|x=2= 3-3(2)2 = - 9

Since it's a normal not tangent, m'= -1/m

=> slope of the normal, m'= -1/-9 = 1/9

To determine the ordinate of the given point, substitute x=2 in the original eqn.

y(2)=2(3-22)= - 2  :. (x1,y1) = (2,-2)

Now, using the eqn of a line (y-y1)=m'(x-x1),

(y- -2)=1/9 (x-2) yielding,

9y = x - 20

 

Q3: Find the equation of the tangent to the curve y=4x2-12x+7 at the point (2,-1).

Solution

dy/dx=8x-12 => dy/dx|x=2= 8(2)-12 = 4

ie m=4 and (x1,y1) = (2,-1)

:. (y- -1) = 4(x-2) leading to

y = 4x - 9

 

Q4: If y=x3-x2-x+6, find the values of x at the turning point.

Solution

dy/dx=3x2-2x-1

At the turning point, dy/dx=0

Setting 3x2-2x-1=0 and solving, we find

x=1 and x= -⅓ 

Notice we didn't have to say which value of x corresponds to the maximum or minimum value. All we wanted was the value of x at the turning points, Just that.

 

PUME Examples

The minimum value of (x) = x2 - 4x + 5 in the interval [1, -1] is

A. -2, B. -12, C. 4, D. 5

 

A (2005/2006, no 13)

 

f(x) = x2 - 4x + 5

Firstly, differentiate the above

f'(x) = 2x – 4 

find the value of x in the coordinate (the first value) and substitute for it. In this case the value of x = 1.

f'(x) = 2(1) – 4 = -2 

 

Example

Find the slope of the curve y = 3x3 + 5x2−3 at (-1, 5).

A. 1, B. -1, C. 19, D. -19

 

B (2010/2011, no 4)

y = 3x3 + 5x2−3

differentiate the equation to get m

 = 9x2 + 10x  

m = 9x2 + 10x  

Given that the coordinate = (-1, 5), substitute the value of x which is the first one (-1)

 m = 9(-1)2 + 10(-1) = -1
